nodes.bodyText:
For ease of use by customers, we probably want to treat the keys case-insensitive.
OBJECT_MAPPER.configure(MapperFeature.ACCEPT_CASE_INSENSITIVE_PROPERTIES, true);
That could work, are there any keyword like life cycle states that the kernel is reading as case sensitive? There shouldn't be any other issue.
Ideally it would not be case sensitive, but right now we're looking everything up as lowercase. I put this comment since your JSON properties here are capitalized in pascal case.
Lombok should be able to help with these getters/setters and constructors.
Will double check for getters/setters in all classes.
Any reason not to just put @getter onto the entire class so you don't have to repeat it all the time here?
Makes sense, I think I was trying to hide some of them but ended up adding getters to all. I will update to class level.
This is probably fine, but you could also just use a stream and filter it instead of using removeIf, then return the filtered list. Then you wouldn't need this note at all.
I will do a bit more refactoring after I add in all the range keywords. Will look into stream + filter at that point, thanks for pointing it out
Not sure if we have guidelines yet, but looking at the code so far, the interface should just be PackageConfig and the implementation PackageConfigImpl. Something to discuss briefly post-scrum.
Fine with either approach as long as we are consistent. This is just what I have used in the past. +1 on postscrum discussion.
I know this is WIP, so that's fine, but we have a bigger list of OSes in the Kernel currently if you look at the method pickByOS.
Good catch, going to pull those in.

We're going with the outputstream way of doing it? I commented on Jason's PR earlier and he seemed to like the idea that the caller would pass a File that they want the artifact to be written to. That way the artifact stays out of Java's memory as much as possible.
Leftover from copy pasta, removing that.
Unused?
Leftover again, I initially put test recipes here but realized it just makes a lot more sense to have test packages. Removing.
I don't think this is needed at all. If you just have @AllArgsConstructor from lombok then Jackson should be abel to serialize/deserialize.
Cleaned up as much as possible in new commit. This file has been renamed to PackageRecipe.java to address some confusion by other reviewers.

[nit]
Lombok for getters and constructor. @Getter and @AllArgsConstructor.
Done
Very likely this may want to throw something.
Updated
What's this for? It's not being used.
I'm not sure it's necessary to have an interface or a class for that matter for lifecycle, if it's deserialized as Map<String, Object> from the recipe, we can work with that directly.
Removed, this was a placeholder but based on recent discussions it's not needed anymore
+1 for not necessary. By the name suggested, it's lifecycle data mode. So interface seems unnecessary.
What's this for? It's not being used.
Removed
Why is this needed?
+1, particular why is checked exception? Also do you want to distinguish between retryable or non-retryable? I  would suggest to define specific exceptions with the use cases.
We are preferring checked exceptions always, see: https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/Greengrass/GGC/Greenlake/DevelopmentGuideline/#HExceptionhandling
This is the parent for all Packaging Exceptions. Allows components which don't care to catch individual exceptions to just catch the base and take some decision.
Not sure if this is desired. Why do you want to make the package name case-insensitive?
Good point, switching to equals
Why do we need to override this?
Collections/Maps etc can break if you override only equals and not hashcode. Findbugs also throws a warning.
Replaced with lombok generated code.
Why does PackageConfig need to be an interface? Also why not just name it PackageRecipe?

Package Recipe is the term we're using for the full recipe file. The hierarchy at the moment is:
PackageRecipe.java -> maps to full recipe file
PackageConfig.java -> versioned, maps to the specific section called config in the full recipe
Let's use a consistent way to name unit test. Some of the codebase uses the behavior driven development pattern: "GIVEN...WHEN...THEN".
I was following one of the other test classes, but this makes sense. Updated to GIVEN...WHEN...THEN
This doesn't help when someone needs to update the code. Can you add a readme describing how the versioning works with concrete examples?
There will be a Readme and a quip doc. I'll add more information to the comments as well.
Maybe we've already discussed and decided this but do they have a library(of acceptable size) we can depend on instead of maintaining this? Or do they only have guidelines for specs?
I hadn't found a usable alternative at the time. Have an option now and migrated to using that directly. This file has been removed.
unused, then remove them.
Removing them, will add again if we decide to go ahead and use these.

These two the same. I see a lot of redundant input in this list. We only need one valid input for each category. We should try to be precise when writing unit tests. It makes the code easier to maintain.

This is the full list taken as is from semver.org. I agree there are redundant inputs in the list but at the same time, I don't think there's any reason to modify what the spec website is providing as a complete list of test versions.
I should add a comment to that effect though, it seems to have been lost when I moved these strings around.
This file has been removed.
Same here. Please remove the redundant invalid versions.
nodes.diffHunk:

nodes.bodyText: These are different test cases. Please break them into separate test cases.
Also, in this case specifically, you should be using assertEquals.
You don't need this! The test will fail if an exception is thrown.
Same here. break them into multiple tests.
Probably don't want to throw RuntimeException here.
Looking through other components to see what folks are doing.
Updated to checked exception
This looks unused, if you do need it it probably shouldn't be public?
Removed for this PR
Will be better if we used one term for this, if it's recipe maybe this class should be called recipe?
Renamed to PackageRecipe.java

Should this be called getArtifactProviders? 'getArtifacts' kind of suggests that you are downloading/fetching the actual artifacts but it looks like after this method call you'll still need to call the download method on each artifact provider
Updated
Should this list be managed by Kernel and reused by package manager if it needs to?
It's possible the kernel list differs from what individual recipes have. I considered reusing the kernel list initially but I don't think we want the hard link when it's very simple to avoid.
Don't see how this is used, suppose it will be in the following PR? Will it talk to the cloud service? If it doesn't then maybe call it LocalPackageStore or something
Yes, creating a second PR for implementations of this interface.
Nit - the code here is self explanatory, probably don't need this documentation
This file has been removed.
Nit - is this a TODO? maybe we should mark all TODOs as TODOs so it's easier to find them for IDEs
This file has been removed.
Remove this now?
This file has been removed.
Was this for debugging, want to remove it now?
Is this a way to implement recipe schema versions or is it temporary until we finalize the format? It looks like there will be a bunch of changes whenever the format changes
Schema versions. This is intended to change every time we change the format as well as to maintain compatibility for existing formats as multiple people iterate on specific sections of the recipe.
What's the point of the math? Isn't the hashcode of that string good enough?
Copy pasta, removing the math.
Probably also needs method to perform cleanup or at least list all cached packages so you can determine what can be deleted.
Will be added later, seemed redundant to include it in this PR, it's already long enough :)
The order should be (expected value, actual value). So I believe you need to flip this one and some others.
Done
Remove this, just throw from the test case. Here and everywhere else too.
Done
Use assertThrows here.
Fixed
What is this %s here?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@
+---
+RecipeTemplateVersion: '2020-01-25'
+PackageName: ConveyorBelt
+Description: Test recipe for Evergreen packages
+Publisher: Me
+Version: '1.0.0'
+Config:
+  Platform:
+    Default:
+      lifecycle:
+        install:
+          skipif: onpath git
+          script: sudo apt-get install git
+      artifacts:
+        - %s/ConveyorBelt-1.0.0/conveyor_artifact.txt

nodes.bodyText: Need to insert the absolute path for the artifact during test run. The %s is filled in while tests are running.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@
+---
+RecipeTemplateVersion: '2020-01-25'
+PackageName: ConveyorBelt
+Description: Test recipe for Evergreen packages
+Publisher: Me
+Version: '1.0.0'
+Config:
+  Platform:
+    Default:
+      lifecycle:
+        install:
+          skipif: onpath git
+          script: sudo apt-get install git
+      artifacts:
+        - %s/ConveyorBelt-1.0.0/conveyor_artifact.txt

nodes.bodyText: Is it data model? If it's data model, why does it mix with control logic? For example, PackageConfigFormat interface. The data model shouldn't decide artifact provider. The controlling logic decides what artifact provider to use in term of data model artifact type.
Are you thinking of creating a separate class called PackageRecipeBuilder or something similar?
As discussed, the initializer code has been removed from package model. The only remaining piece is the ArtifactProvider which will be moved in a follow up PR.
Again, data model shouldn't control deserializing itself. We should separate control and data flows.
See comment above
Can you try to use lombok to generate equals and hashcode? why do we need to write ourselves?
Done

I understand the reasons behind versioned template. But my arguments are if name and version are fixed, why not artifacts and dependencies? Oppositely, are the package name and version ever fixed? for example, won't we decide to alter the name in the future? Also this creates another level indentation in recipe file.
Have you thought different approach for this purpose? For example, use different recipe/package model to map to different template version completely?
Do we have to decide how we support recipe template version now? Can we add the support when we need to? I don't think it's one-way door.

I don't quite understand this comment, if the package name/version have changed, it's not the same package. Why would we allow that to change in the code? And the recipe schema version to be used is defined by the Recipe file using the RecipeTemplateVersion variable. We don't force a mapping.
We did discuss earlier that adding schema versioning support is important. And well, at this point the code is already done so I don't think there's any reason to not merge it in?
As discussed, we'll keep this for now and revisit the overall schema design if needed in a followup PR

Why is it an interface? Isn't cache internal to package manager? Will we have different implementation of package cache? What's this store's relationship with package registry/database? Is it playing both roles of registry and cache?

This is playing both roles at the moment. But as we discussed, in my working model I didn't want to have a separate registry. Since that has changed, this can still be both roles but needs to have the code for registry added to implementation.
Also, this is an interface to allow for different types of Package Stores or different implementations. This same interface can be reused to interact with EPMS, S3 etc. The package manager PR will make this a little clearer. We can modify this interface as needed while working on that.
Pull request with Local Store implementation - #68

We will need parameters section from the recipe in here as well, maybe an inner class of this with parameter name, default value and type. But if you are merging this soon, I can add that in my pull request
As discussed, this will be in a followup PR

Get package/recipe implementation would be different based on the source, but I'm thinking cache and the copy location and hence the implementation should be the same for all package stores?  Should this be an abstract class instead of an interface so you could move these methods to a common place?

Copy could also be different depending whether we choose to perform a direct copy from store to some location. Not sure if that's the best idea in terms of implementation but it's straightforward.
Is it ok to refactor this in a follow up PR when we add more types of stores? Depending on the situation, this can always be updated to abstract class.
Is this temporary since we only have local artifact provider right now?
Yes, I didn't want to spend effort into coming up with keywords for this particular PR. This will likely move to it's own parser class in a follow up PR.

I think there are no strong reason to have another level of indentation now. The template versioning problem can be solved by the other way. Adding this config tab is especially not necessary when thinking from customer point of view.
Discussed offline, this will be addressed in followup PR, resolving
Like we have discussed, model shouldn't decide handlers. Using applicable artifact provider to process artifact is controlling logic. Can we return artifacts instead of artifact provider?
Discussed offline, this will be addressed in followup PR, resolving
